drugs: Diphtheria, Tetanus, Pertussis, and Poliovirus Vaccine

0.title: Generic Names
0.mono: Diphtheria, Tetanus, Pertussis, and Poliovirus Vaccine

1.title: Pediatric Dosing
1.mono: Diphtheria, pertussis and tetanus triple and polio vaccination: (4 to 6 years) A single 0.5-mL dose IM in the deltoid muscle (preferred site)

3.title: Indications
3.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
Diphtheria, pertussis and tetanus triple and polio vaccination

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono:
• Encephalopathy (eg, coma, decreased level of consciousness, prolonged seizures) within 7 days of a previous dose of pertussis-containing vaccine and not attributable to other causes
  • Progressive neurologic disorder (eg, infantile spasms, uncontrolled epilepsy, progressive encephalopathy); defer vaccination until neurologic status is stabilized
  • Severe allergic reaction (eg, anaphylaxis) to any component of the product, including neomycin and polymyxin B in Kinrix(R), or to a previous dose of any diphtheria toxoid, tetanus toxoid, pertussis-containing vaccine, or inactivated poliovirus vaccine

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• Cardiovascular:
  • -- Collapse or shock-like state (hypotonic-hyporesponsive episode) within 48 hours of administration of any prior pertussis-containing vaccine; evaluate benefit/risk prior to administration
  • -- Syncope that may be accompanied by transient neurological signs (ie, visual disturbance, paresthesia, tonic-clonic limb movements) may occur
  • Immunologic:
  • -- Anaphylactic or acute hypersensitivity reaction may occur
  • -- Reduced immune response to vaccine may occur in immunocompromised patients including those receiving immunosuppressive therapy (eg, corticosteroid, antimetabolite, alkylating, or cytotoxic medications; radiation)
  • -- Latex allergy; tip cap of prefilled syringes may contain natural latex rubber
  • -- Arthus-type hypersensitivity reaction after a previous tetanus toxoid-containing vaccine; defer vaccination until at least 10 years since last tetanus toxoid vaccine
  • Neurologic:
  • -- Seizure, with or without fever, occurring within 3 days of administration of any prior pertussis-containing vaccine; evaluate benefit/risk prior to administration
  • -- Guillain-Barre syndrome within 6 weeks of administration of any prior tetanus toxoid-containing vaccine; evaluate benefit/risk prior to administration
  • Other:
  • -- Fever of 40.5 degrees C (105 degrees F) or higher within 48 hours of administration of any prior pertussis-containing vaccine and unrelated to other causes; evaluate benefit/risk prior to administration
  • -- Crying that is persistent and inconsolable for 3 hours or more and occurring within 48 hours of administration of any prior pertussis-containing vaccine; evaluate benefit/risk prior to administration
  • -- Moderate or severe acute illness with or without fever; defer vaccination unless the benefit of protection outweighs the risk of an adverse reaction
  • -- Children with high seizure risk; consider prophylactic antipyretics with administration and for 24 hours after vaccination to reduce postvaccination fever
  • -- Can be administered during pregnancy if there is a risk for exposure to wild-type poliovirus infection
  • -- Revaccination in patients with unknown vaccination history may require serologic testing; an increased rate of adverse events may occur after the fourth and fifth DTaP dose

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Dermatologic:Erythema at injection site (36.6% to 59.1%), Injection site pain (57% to 77.4%), Swelling at injection site (26% to 40.2%)
  • Gastrointestinal:Loss of appetite (15.5%)
  • Musculoskeletal:Myalgia (53.8%)
  • Neurologic:Headache (15.6%), Somnolence (19.1%)
  • Other:Fever (6% to 16%), Increase in circumference, Limb (36% to 68.1%), Malaise (35%)
Serious
  • Cardiovascular:Syncope
  • Endocrine metabolic:Dehydration, Hypernatremia
  • Gastrointestinal:Gastroenteritis

sub.title: Synonyms
sub.mono:
• DTaP-IPV - Diphtheria and Tetanus Toxoids and Acellular Pertussis Adsorbed and Inactivated Poliovirus Vaccine
  • DTaP and Polio Vaccine
  • Diphtheria Toxoid, Adsorbed; Pertussis Vaccine, Acellular; Tetanus Toxoid; and Poliovirus Vaccine, Inactivated

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono:
• Diphtheria: Following IM injection, diphtheria toxoid induces the formation of neutralizing antibodies to diphtheria toxin.
  • Tetanus: Following IM injection, tetanus toxoid induces the formation of neutralizing antibodies to tetanus toxin.
  • Pertussis: Following IM injection, acellular pertussis vaccine induces the formation of several antibodies thought to be clinically protective. The levels of antibody necessary for protection have not been determined.
  • Inactivated Poliovirus Vaccine (IPV): Following IM injection, IPV induces the production of neutralizing antibodies against each poliovirus serotype correlating with protection against poliomyelitis.

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
• General Information
    For IM use only; do not administer IV, intradermally, or subcutaneously.
  • Intramuscular
    • (Quadracel(TM)) Shake vial well to create uniform, white, cloudy suspension prior to aseptic withdrawal of dose
    • (Kinrix(R)) Shake vial or prefilled syringe vigorously to get a homogenous, turbid, white suspension; do not use vial if resuspension does not occur
    • (Kinrix(R)) Vial or prefilled syringe are intended for single use only; a sterile needle is required when using the prefilled syringes (not supplied)
    • Deltoid muscle is preferred site of injection
    • Use separate syringes (do not mix) when administering concomitantly with other vaccines
    • (Kinrix(R)) Tip cap of the prefilled syringes may contain natural rubber latex; vial stopper and plungers are not made with natural rubber latex

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono: No specific monitoring has been determined.

11.title: How Supplied
11.mono:
• Kinrix
    Intramuscular Suspension: (Diphtheria Toxoid, Adsorbed - Pertussis Vaccine, Acellular - Poliovirus Vaccine, Inactivated - Tetanus Toxoid) 25 Lf U/0.5 ML-58 MCG/0.5 ML-80 D Antigen U/0.5 ML-10 Lf U/0.5 ML
  • Quadracel
    Intramuscular Suspension: (Diphtheria Toxoid, Adsorbed - Pertussis Vaccine, Acellular - Poliovirus Vaccine, Inactivated - Tetanus Toxoid) 15 Lf U/0.5 ML-48 MCG/0.5 ML-80 D Antigen U/0.5 ML-5 Lf U/0.5 ML

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Instruct caregiver to report any of the following symptoms: a temperature of 40.5 degrees C (105 degrees F) or higher; persistent, inconsolable crying lasting 3 hours or more; a collapse or shock-like state (hypotonic, hyporesponsive); or a seizure with or without fever.
  • Side effects may include injection site reactions (pain, erythema, swelling), drowsiness, fever, loss of appetite, myalgia, malaise, and headache.
